There has been much comment on campus in the past few
years about the change in .emphasis at Hopkins away from the
training of scientists and scholars aria toward pure research.
This feeling was pointed up by the comment of a certain professor
who was heard to remark at a party, "The students? Oh, the
students. I never think of the students!"
The university treasurer's report, released this week, though
hardly comprehensible to us, does reveal some trends worth consideration. Most important to students on the Homewood campus
perhaps, is that the total income from tuition in the faculty
of philosophy and the school of engineering for the year ended

of the university to do this work was never questioned by us, we
were afraid that the ideal of a "research institution" might be
realized at a cost to the student.

comments of several members of the administration in regard to

to return to greater support for basic educational departments."
Carlyle Barton, president of the Board of Trustees, in a
statement on the treasurer's report supported this position further,
"The university's distinguished record in training men for
business and industrial careers, its accomplishments in original
research, and its unique function of training those who often form

Your Money's Worth ...
There has been much comment on campus in the past few
years about the change in .emphasis at Hopkins away from the
training of scientists and scholars aria toward pure research.
This feeling was pointed up by the comment of a certain professor
who was heard to remark at a party, "The students? Oh, the
students. I never think of the students!"
The university treasurer's report, released this week, though
hardly comprehensible to us, does reveal some trends worth consideration. Most important to students on the Homewood campus
perhaps, is that the total income from tuition in the faculty
of philosophy and the school of engineering for the year ended
June 30, 1954, was $1,896,635 while expenditures in the same
branches of the university totaled $7,619,813. This shows in crude
terms almost a four to one return on tuition paid by students.
Above figures may be compared with the income from tuition
at the medical school, $244,901—and a total expenditure of
$3,739,004. While the crude return on investment of tuition at
Homewood is almost four to one, at the school of medicine it is
15 to one. This tremendous difference is explained by the
difference in amount of endowment income ($349,509 for Homewood, $780,496 for the medical school) and the difference in
restricted gifts ($347,227 for Homewood, $1,638,845 for the medical school). The total funds available to the medical school from
these sources is $2,429,341 while Homewood takes in only $696,736.
President Reed's Comlnemoration Day ad.dress last year gave
the students little cause for reassurance that they had not been
forgotten. Most of his speech was devoted to a description of the
work carried on by various branches of the University. He seemed
particularly interested in the Apecial research being carried on—
especially under government contract. While the right and duty
of the university to do this work was never questioned by us, we
were afraid that the ideal of a "research institution" might be
realized at a cost to the student.
.It was therefore with considerable relief that we noted the
comments of several members of the administration in regard to
the Treasurer's Report. President Reed said, "A study of the
report indietates that reStrieted funds for specific projects are
more readily available, than are funds for the basic university
departments which by their excellence attract these special pro/ jects. We hope all elements of society join us to reverse this trend,
to return to greater support for basic educational departments."
Carlyle Barton, president of the Board of Trustees, in a
statement on the treasurer's report supported this position further,
"The university's distinguished record in training men for
business and industrial careers, its accomplishments in original
research, and its unique function of training those who often form
the core of other faculties and the research of industry cannot
be allowed to decline through any interruption of this huge
volume of 'special purpose funds.' However, the heart of the
university is its basic departments and 'their teachers and
scholars supported from general funds. We are striving to maintain a realistic balance between the resources of these basic
elements of the university and those of the specialized activities
it has been asked to undertake by industry, government and
foundation."
Cognizance of the problem is by no means its solution. Certainly if what Mr. Barton' calls the "basic elements of the university" are to continue developing they shall need an ever
increasing amount of capital with which to do this.
